College of Chemistry Jilin University Changchun Jilin 130012 China Graphical abstract Development of efficient, selective and low-cost photocatalysts, ideally constructed from Earth-abundant elements, is still a big challenge for CO2 photoreduction. Herein, adopting mixed halides strategy, the activity of all-inorganic perovskites toward CO2 reduction is enhanced sharply under simulated sunlight without photosensitizer, meanwhile maintaining high selectivity of CO and CH4 production. Via regulating ratio of Br and Cl, the yield of CO and CH4 changes obviously and the optimized catalyst is CsPb(Br0.5/Cl0.5)3 with a total yield of CO and CH4 up to 875 μmol/g (selectivity of 99%) which outperforms any other reported halide perovskites and is 4.5 and 9.1 folds higher than that of CsPbBr3 and CsPbCl3 under the same condition. The efficient charge separation and moderate stability in mixed-halide perovskites may account for the excellent performance in CO2 reduction. This study may provide a new strategy in design of high performance and low-cost halide perovskite materials for photocatalysis. Keywords Mixed-halide perovskites CO2 reduction Photocatalysis Simulated sunlight 1 Introduction For the large consumption of limited fossil fuels and release of carbon dioxide (CO2), the demand for clean and renewable energy is urgently increasing [1–3]. Of particular interest is the innovation of artificial photosynthesis which lays a solid foundation for the production of renewable fuels by harvesting solar energy [4,5]. Recently, a variety of materials, including metal oxides, sulfides, and organic semiconductor materials, have been employed as photocatalysts for CO2 reduction [6–10]. Although significant progress has been made in CO2 reduction with these materials as photocatalysts [11–19], most of them can only be active in the range of ultraviolet (UV) light and usually exhibit poor selectivity [20–22]. Moreover, the demand for photosensitizer (usually noble-metal complexes) is indispensable in most CO2 photoreduction systems [21,23]. Furthermore, the unrecyclable utilization of the substance will be a negative impact on the economy and environment. Thus, development of efficient, selective and low-cost photocatalysts for photocatalytic CO2 reduction without additional additive is of great importance. Recently, halide perovskite materials have attracted enormous attention for their outstanding electronic and optical properties [24–29] and shown promising optoelectronic applications, especially in photovoltaics [30,31], light-emitting diodes [32–34] and photodetectors [35–37]. By tuning the compositions or modifying synthesis methods, high stability, good crystallinity and low trap densities of halide perovskite materials could be achieved [24,26]. The power conversion efficiency of perovskite solar cells has developed rapidly from 3.8 to 22.1% within a few years [38,39]. Benefiting from their excellent optical properties and unique electronic structures, recently, halide perovskite materials have been applied for photocatalysts. For example, in 2016, Nam and co-workers firstly realized photocatalytic hydrogen iodide (HI) splitting using methylammonium lead iodide (MAPbI3) as catalyst in saturated aqueous solutions [40]. Subsequently, Tüysüz et al. found that the polymerization of 2,2,5,2″-ter-3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene could be promoted using cesium lead iodide perovskite quantum dots (CsPbI3 QDs) as photocatalysts under visible light illumination [41]. Su and colleagues firstly reported CsPbBr3 QDs as photocatalysts for converting CO2 into solar fuels in nonaqueous media [42]. Although halide perovskite materials have exhibited attractive performance in photocatalysis [40–46], they are still in the initial stage. Especially for CO2 photoreduction, the yield is still limited in tens of micromole per gram of catalyst. Herein, mixed halides strategy was adopted to promote the activity of all-inorganic perovskites in CO2 photoreduction. A serial of mixed-halide perovskites CsPb(Brx/Cl1−x)3 (x = 0.7, 0.5, 0.3) with a cubic phase are explored as photocatalysts and high efficiency and selectivity in converting CO2 into CO and CH4 are achieved under simulated sunlight and absence of photosensitizer (Fig. 1 ). The ratio of Br and Cl in CsPb(Brx/Cl1−x)3 has a significant impact on the catalytic efficiency. The optimized catalyst is CsPb(Br0.5/Cl0.5)3 with a total yield of CO and CH4 up to 875 μmol/g (selectivity of 99%) which is around 4.5 and 9.1 times higher than the performance of CsPbBr3 and CsPbCl3 in the same phase and outperforms any other reported perovskites. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials All chemicals were directly used without further purification. Cesium carbonate (Cs2CO3, 99%, Aladdin), lead (II) bromide (PbBr2, 99.5%, Aladdin), lead (II) chloride (PbCl2, 99.5%, Aladdin), oleylamine (OAm, technical grade 90%, Aladdin), oleic acid (OA, technical grade 90%, Alfa Aesar), 1-octadecene (ODE, technical grade 90%, Aladdin), trioctylphosphine (TOP, Strem, 97%), ethyl acetate (AR, Aladdin), hexanes (AR, Aladdin), dimethyl formamide (DMF, AR), toluene (AR, Aladdin), hexanoic acid (AR, Aladdin), octylamine (AR, Aladdin). 2.2 Synthesis Preparation of Cs-oleate. Firstly, Cs2CO3 (0.8140 g), OA (2.5 mL) and ODE (10 mL) were added into a 50-mL 2-neck round bottomed flask, and then the flask was evacuated for about 5 min at room temperature. Then the flask was refilled with nitrogen and evacuated at 120 °C for 30 min, then maintaining 120 °C until obtaining the transparent solution. Before using, the Cs-oleate solution was heated until totally dissolved. Synthesis of colloidal CsPb(Brx/Cl1−x)3 (x = 1, 0.7, 0.5, 0.3, 0) nanocrystals. The halide perovskite CsPb(Brx/Cl1−x)3 (x = 1, 0.7, 0.5, 0.3, 0) nanocrystals were prepared according to the reported literature [47]. Take CsPbBr3 nanocrystals as an example. PbBr2 (0.0661 g), OAm (0.8 mL), OA (0.8 mL), and ODE (5 mL) were added to a 50-mL 2-neck round bottomed flask. The flask was evacuated and refilled with N2 when the solution was heated to 120 °C for 30 min. After that, the solution was increased to 185 °C. At 185 °C, dried OAm (0.8 mL) and dried OA (0.8 mL) was injected to solubilize the solution. Then the Cs-oleate (0.064 mL) was swiftly injected into the reaction system and after 5 s the solution was cooled with an ice bath. The nanocrystals were collected by centrifugation at 8000 rpm for 5 min, and then washed with hexane and ethyl acetate for five times. For CsPbCl3 nanocrystals, 1 mL of TOP was required to solubilize PbCl2. Synthesis of CsPbBr3 quantum dots with the orthorhombic phase [42]. Firstly, PbBr2 (367.01 mg) was fully dissolved in the mixture of DMF (20 mL), hexanoic acid (232.32 mg) and octylamine (258.48 mg). Subsequently, 1 mL of Cs-oleate solution was added to this solution. Finally, 0.5 mL of the mixed solution was added into a flask with 20 mL of toluene, followed centrifuging and washing process (by ethyl acetate) twice. 2.3 Materials characterization The powder X-ray diffraction patterns (PXRD) were recorded on a SmartLab X-ray diffractometer. The morphology and nanostructure were investigated on transmission electron microscope (TEM) and high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) (JEM-2100Plus). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) characterizations were performed on an Escalab 250 instrument with a monochromatized Al Kα X-ray sources. The absorption behavior of the samples was studied by the UV–vis spectrometer (Shimadzu UV-2600). UV–vis diffuse reflection spectroscopy (DRS) was obtained on a U-3010 spectrophotometer (Hitachi, Japan). Photoluminescence (PL) spectra were scanned on a photoluminescence spectrometer (Hitachi F-4600), under an excitation wavelength of 362 nm except for CsPbCl3 nanocrystals (excited by 320 nm). The elemental analysis is carried out by inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS). The film thickness of photoelectrode was determined by Scanning Electron Microscope (SEM). The product of the photocatalytic reaction was tested by the GC-9800 spectrometer. The HP 6890GC-5973MSD gas chromatography-mass spectrometer (GC-MS) was employed to analyze the CO product generated from the 13CO2 (98% enriched) isotope experiments. 2.4 Electrochemistry measurements Fabrication of the CsPb(Brx/Cl1−x)3 (x = 0.7, 0.5, 0.3) photoelectrodes. The ITO substrate was cleaned by sonicating sequentially in deionized water, alcohol and acetone, each for 10 min. The ITO substrate was divided into the size of approximately 1 cm × 1 cm. A fixed amount of CsPb(Brx/Cl1−x)3 (x = 1, 0.7, 0.5, 0.3, 0) toluene suspension was subsequently dropped onto the ITO substrate. The as-prepared photoelectrodes were subsequently dried at room temperature overnight. All the photoelectrochemical characterizations were performed on the electrochemical workstation (CHI660e, CH Instruments, Inc., USA) with a three-electrode configuration with the assembled photoelectrodes as the working electrode, the Pt mesh as the counter electrode and the Ag/AgCl (in 3 M KCl) as the reference electrode. The ethyl acetate with 0.1 M tetrabutylammonium hexafluorophosphate (TBAPF6) was filled in the cell as electrolyte. The light source and the light density were identical with that in the photocatalytic CO2 reduction test. 2.5 Photocatalytic reaction Photocatalytic performance tests. The photocatalytic CO2 reduction was conducted in a homemade 75 mL sealed cell with 0.5 mg CsPb(Brx/Cl1−x)3 (x = 1, 0.7, 0.5, 0.3, 0) nanocrystals as the catalysts and 6 mL ethyl acetate as the solvent. Before the reduction, high purity CO2 (99.99%) gas was bubbled in the ethyl acetate solvent for around 20 min until the CO2 concentration reached saturation and dissolved oxygen was removed completely. A 300 W Xenon lamp with AM 1.5 filter was used as the light source. The distance between the homemade sealed cell and the 300 W xenon lamp is about 8 cm and the sample geometry of irradiation was about 2 cm × 3 cm. The light intensity was around 200 mW/cm2. All of the experiments were carried out under ambient pressure and the reaction system was kept at 20 °C under a cooling water system. The gaseous products generated during CO2 photocatalytic reduction were collected by a 1 mL syringe and then immediately analyzed by GC-9800 equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID), and a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) after 9 h. Control experiments. The control experiment was conducted in a homemade 75 mL sealed cell with 0.5 mg CsPb(Br0.5/Cl0.5)3 nanocrystals as the catalysts and 6 mL ethyl acetate as the solvent. Before the reduction, high purity Ar (99.99%) gas was bubbled in the ethyl acetate solvent for around 20 min until the dissolved oxygen was removed completely. A 300 W xenon lamp with AM 1.5 filter was used as the light source. After 9 h, the gaseous products were collected by a 1 mL syringe and then immediately analyzed by GC-9800 equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID), and a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). Isotopic experiment. The isotopic experiment was conducted in a homemade 75 mL sealed cell with 0.5 mg CsPb(Br0.5/Cl0.5)3 nanocrystals as the catalysts and 6 mL ethyl acetate as the solvent. Before the reduction, 13CO2 (98%) gas was bubbled in the ethyl acetate solvent for around 20 min until the dissolved oxygen was removed completely. A 300 W xenon lamp with AM 1.5 filter was used as the light source. After 9 h, the 13C-labeled product was tested by GC-MS. 3 Results and discussion The monodispersed mixed-halide perovskites CsPb(Brx/Cl1−x)3 (x = 0.7, 0.5, 0.3) were synthesized according to the well-developed hot injection method [47]. As control in catalytic experiment, CsPbBr3 and CsPbCl3 nanocrystals were also prepared through the same approach. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns show a pure cubic phase of the as-prepared CsPb(Brx/Cl1−x)3 (x = 1, 0.7, 0.5, 0.3, 0) nanocrystals (Fig. 2 e), which is consistent with the previous reports [47,48]. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images presented in Fig. 2a and Fig. S1† exhibit that all CsPb(Brx/Cl1−x)3 (x = 1, 0.7, 0.5, 0.3, 0) crystals are cubic shape with a size around 10.5 nm (Fig. 2c). Such small particle size will provide guarantee of a large specific surface area for catalysis. Depending on the high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) image (Fig. 2b), the lattice parameter of the CsPb(Br0.5/Cl0.5)3 materials is 0.57 nm suggesting the as-prepared materials are highly crystalline in perovskite structure. Moreover, the energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) spectra reveal the existence of Cs, Pb, Br and Cl elements in CsPb(Br0.5/Cl0.5)3 materials (Fig. 2d). We examined the surface chemical binding of CsPb(Brx/Cl1−x)3 (x = 1, 0.7, 0.5, 0.3, 0) materials with X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) (Fig. S2†). The peaks of Cs 3d of CsPbBr3 (x = 1) at 724.0 and 738.1 eV are gradually red-shift to 723.8 and 737.8 eV (CsPbCl3, x = 0), respectively (Fig. 3 a). For the peaks of Pb 4f, they individually exhibit blue-shift from 137.8 and 142.7 eV of CsPbBr3 to 138.0 and 142.9 eV of CsPbCl3 (Fig. 3b). These indicate that bonding environment of Cs and Pb atoms is changed via tuning the ratios of Br/Cl. The peaks of Br 3d and/or Cl 2p in CsPb(Brx/Cl1−x)3 (x = 1, 0.7, 0.5, 0.3, 0) are almost unchanged (Fig. 3c, d). To better understand the actual ratio of Br/Cl in the synthesized perovskites, the elemental analysis is carried out by ICP-MS (Table S1†), which indicates that the actual ratio is generally consistent with the molar feed ratio. In the following experiments, we studied the optical properties of CsPb(Brx/Cl1−x)3 materials. Firstly, using ethyl acetate as a solvent, light absorption property of CsPb(Brx/Cl1−x)3 was measured. CsPb(Brx/Cl1−x)3 exhibit a good absorption toward the visible light, ranging from 400 to 700 nm (Fig. 4 a), which is quite wider than the typical semiconductors, such as TiO2, ZnO [6,49,50]. With x value increases, the absorption peaking at 520 nm (CsPbBr3) gradually shifts to 420 nm (CsPbCl3). For semiconductor, the band edge positions have a significant influence on the catalytic reactivity. Hence, the band edge positions of CsPb(Brx/Cl1−x)3 (x = 1, 0.7, 0.5, 0.3, 0) materials were studied. First, the band gap (E g) of them was decided by UV–vis diffuse reflection spectroscopy (DRS, Fig. S3†) based on Tauc method [51]. Fig. 4b shows the (αhν)2 versus hν curves of CsPb(Brx/Cl1−x)3 (x = 1, 0.7, 0.5, 0.3, 0) materials with a direct band gap [52]. The E g values of CsPb(Brx/Cl1−x)3 (x = 1, 0.7, 0.5, 0.3, 0) were from 2.33 to 2.98 eV (Table 1 ) based on the X-axis intercept of the Tauc plot. The valence band (E VB) of CsPb(Brx/Cl1−x)3 (x = 1, 0.7, 0.5, 0.3, 0) materials are determined by Valence-band XPS (VB XPS, Fig. 4c and Fig. S4†). The conduction band (E CB) are determined by the equation [53]: E CB = E VB - E g According to the band edge positions in Table 1, we can find that E VB enhanced with the increase of Cl content in CsPb(Brx/Cl1−x)3, while very little change of E CB was observed. Thus, the E VB depends more strongly on the halide composition than E CB. In addition, E CB levels of all as-prepared halide perovskites are higher than the reductive potential of CO2 to CO (−0.5 eV). Under the excitation of 362 nm (except CsPbCl3 which was excited by 320 nm), emission spectra of CsPb(Brx/Cl1−x)3 (x = 1, 0.7, 0.5, 0.3, 0) materials were collected. The emission band peaking at 517 nm is observed on CsPbBr3 and with the enhancement of Cl content, the peak is gradually shifted to 413 nm (Fig. 4d). To investigate the catalytic activity of mixed-halide perovskite toward CO2 reduction, the catalytic experiment was carried out following the reaction condition reported by Su and co-workers in which only perovskites and ethyl acetate were used in the system [42]. As a control experiment, the catalytic activity of CsPbBr3 and CsPbCl3 was also investigated. Firstly, a certain amount of halide perovskites was put into a quartz tube containing 6 mL ethyl acetate. After irradiation by Xe-300 lamp with AM 1.5 filter within 9 h, CO and CH4 are generated as the main gas product and the yield is changed with the alteration of Br/Cl ratios in perovskites (Fig. 5 a, Tables S2† and S3†). With CsPbBr3 as a catalyst, the yield of CO and CH4 is 135 and 60 μmol/g, respectively. After displacing Br with Cl at x = 0.7, the yield of CO and CH4 enhances slightly up to 156 and 72 μmol/g. When using CsPb(Br0.5/Cl0.5)3 as a catalyst, the CO generation undergoes a sharp increase to 767 μmol/g which is 5.7-fold and 4.9-fold higher than that of pure CsPbBr3 and CsPb(Br0.7/Cl0.3)3, while CH4 only exhibits a slight enhancement (108 μmol/g) (Fig. S5a†). However, further enhancing the Cl content (x = 0.3 or 0), the production amount of CO and CH4 in CsPb(Br0.3/Cl0.7)3 or CsPbCl3 presents an obvious decrease. From these results, we can find Cl introduction has a significant influence on the activity of CO2 reduction in this photocatalytic system. The optimal catalyst is CsPb(Br0.5/Cl0.5)3 with a total catalytic yield of CO and CH4 up to 875 μmol/g which is around 4.5 and 9.1 times higher than the performance of CsPbBr3 and CsPbCl3 materials. What’s more, the common byproduct H2 is avoided in all of CsPb(Brx/Cl1−x)3 catalyst and the selectivity toward CO and CH4 is up to 99%. CsPbBr3 QDs with the orthorhombic phase are first reported as a photocatalyst for CO2 photoreduction [42]. To get an unambiguous evaluation about mixed-halide strategy in CO2 photoreduction, the orthorhombic CsPbBr3 sample was employed as a catalyst in our experimental condition (Fig. S5b†). After 9 h reaction, around 112 μmol/g CO and 33 μmol/g CH4 are produced and the total generation amount (145 μmol/g) is 1/6 of CsPb(Br0.5/Cl0.5)3 and comparable with that of cubic CsPbBr3 (195 μmol/g). Compared with the mixed-halide strategy, crystal phase (orthorhombic or cubic) has a little effect on the CO2 photoreduction performance. Moreover, the total yield of CsPb(Br0.5/Cl0.5)3 perovskite toward CO2 reduction is much better than that of reported popular catalysts, such as TiO2, CdS and g-C3N4 under similar condition (Table S4†). To better confirm the advantage of CsPb(Br0.5/Cl0.5)3 perovskite over these materials in CO2 reduction, the activity of g-C3N4 nanosheets and TiO2 (P25) were studied under the same catalytic condition (Table S5†). The photocatalytic results demonstrate that the reactivity of g-C3N4 nanosheets and TiO2 (P25) is around 10-fold and 5-fold lower than that of CsPb(Br0.5/Cl0.5)3 respectively. The CO2 photoreduction activity of CsPb(Br0.5/Cl0.5)3 materials within different time was investigated by detecting the amounts of CO and CH4 every three hours (Fig. 5b). Within the period, the outputs of CO and CH4 are 250 ± 20 and 25.0 ± 2 μmol/g, respectively. These results present that CO and CH4 almost linearly increase during the 9 h irradiation. These results imply that CsPb(Br0.5/Cl0.5)3 materials might have a moderate stability during photocatalysis. To compare the performance of different catalysts via tuning ratios of Br/Cl during different reaction time, the experiments were carried out (Fig. S6†). The higher generation speed of CO than that of CH4 may result from the needed multi-electrons pathway in CH4 formation. The decrease of CH4 amount after 9 h reaction may ascribe to the discontinuous irradiation which severely affects electrons accumulation to feed 8 electrons route. The control experiment was investigated to determine the source of the gas product under an inert Ar gas atmosphere. After 9 h irradiation, CO and CO2 were generated with the amount of 94 and 430 μmol/g by CsPb(Br0.5/Cl0.5)3, respectively. The CO yield under Ar is around one-in-eight of that under saturated CO2 (767 μmol/g) which means that a small quantity of CO generated from the photosynthesis system due to partial photooxidation of ethyl acetate. To further make sure the carbon source of the reaction product, gas chromatography-mass spectrometer (GC-MS) was used to detect CO under 13CO2 atmosphere using CsPb(Br0.5/Cl0.5)3 as catalysts (Fig. 6 ). The result of isotopic experiment indicates that about 85% of CO comes from 13CO2 photoreduction. Besides activity, the stability of a catalyst is another significant factor affecting the catalytic efficiency. To illuminate the stability of mixed-halide perovskite materials, we studied the crystalline phase after photocatalysis. No obvious changes in PXRD patterns of CsPb(Brx/Cl1−x)3 (x = 0.7, 0.5, 0.3) are observed after photocatalysis. Contrast to mixed-halide perovskite, the PXRD pattern of CsPbCl3 after catalysis was kept intact but the one of CsPbBr3 (Fig. 7 a) shows a few new peaks (CsPb2Br5). These results imply mixed-halide perovskite materials may have better stability than that of bare CsPbBr3, and indicate that the introduction of Cl in halide perovskite could be a promising way to enhance the stability of perovskite in CO2 photoreduction to some extent. Considering the PXRD results, the reusable experiment was conducted (Fig. S7†). After second recycle (corresponding to 18 h reaction), around 42% and 56% decrease in CO and CH4 generation with CsPb(Br0.5/Cl0.5)3 as catalyst was observed, however, after third recycle (corresponding to 27 h reaction), the yield of both CO and CH4 sharply reduced to 38% and 23%. The decrease of catalytic activity may result from the moderate durability of perovskite materials under the long-time irradiation. For other CsPb(Brx/Cl1−x)3 (x = 0, 0.3, 0.7, 1), with the Cl content enhanced, the reduced degree in reactivity decreased. According to these experiments, the ratio of Br and Cl at 0.5:0.5 should be the most active rather than the most stable. The advantage in band energy and the moderate stability of CsPb(Br0.5/Cl0.5)3 may make it be the most appropriate catalyst for CO2 photoreduction. Given that charge separation plays a crucial role in the redox reaction, transient photocurrent responses were employed to reveal the rooted reason behind the predominant photocatalytic performance of CsPb(Br0.5/Cl0.5)3 materials in CO2 reduction. First, the photoelectrodes were prepared and the thickness of the film cross-section was determined by SEM image of CsPb(Br0.5/Cl0.5)3 photoelectrode (Fig. S8†). The photocurrent responses were collected under Xe-300 lamp with AM 1.5 filter under dark and light conditions. In Fig. 7b, the photocurrent density of CsPb(Br0.5/Cl0.5)3 elevates rapidly up to 4.4 μA/cm2 during light irradiation and then decreases sharply under the dark condition, which can be successively implemented for multiple times. Other mixed-halide perovskites CsPb(Brx/Cl1−x)3 (x = 0.7, 0.3) have similar phenomena during on-off irradiation but with low photocurrent density. These results illuminate the charge separation of CsPb(Br0.5/Cl0.5)3 is more efficient than the other two mixed-halide perovskites. Together with the band energy and the advantage in moderate stability, CsPb(Br0.5/Cl0.5)3 may be the most appropriate catalyst for CO2 photoreduction. 4 Conclusion In summary, we provide a strategy to enhance the CO2 photoreduction efficiency, exploring low-cost and selective mixed-halide perovskite CsPb(Brx/Cl1−x)3 (x = 0.7, 0.5, 0.3) materials as catalysts. Via hot-injection method, these mixed-halide perovskites with cubic phase and a size of 10.5 nm are prepared, which exhibit excellent visible-light absorption property. The E g of these mixed-halide perovskite ranges from 2.51 to 2.83 eV which is smaller than classical semiconductors, such as TiO2 and ZnO. The E CB of them is all around −1.70 eV, higher than the reductive potential of CO2 to CO (−0.5 eV) which provides the guarantee for CO2 photoreduction. Under simulated sunlight and absence of additive of the photosensitizer, mixed-halide perovskites exhibit excellent photocatalytic efficiency and selectivity in converting CO2 to CO and CH4. The ratio of Br and Cl in perovskite materials has a significant effect on the photocatalytic performance. The optimized catalyst is CsPb(Br0.5/Cl0.5)3 with a total amount of 875 μmol/g of CO and CH4 (selectivity of 99%) which is 4.5, 9.1 and 6 folds higher than the yield of CsPbBr3, CsPbCl3 and CsPbBr3 with orthorhombic phase under the same condition. The moderate stability and appropriate band energy of mixed-halide perovskite may account for the high yield of CsPb(Brx/Cl1−x)3. The more efficient charge separation of CsPb(Br0.5/Cl0.5)3 than that of CsPb(Br0.7/Cl0.3)3 and CsPb(Br0.3/Cl0.7)3 may lead to the higher activity of CsPb(Br0.5/Cl0.5)3. What’s more, this activity and selectivity of CsPb(Br0.5/Cl0.5)3 outperform popular semiconductor catalysts, such as TiO2, CdS and g-C3N4. We believe that these findings pave new routes in designing efficient, selective and low-cost perovskite for CO2 photoreduction. coredata.dc:description: Development of efficient, selective and low-cost photocatalysts, ideally constructed from Earth-abundant elements, is still a big challenge for CO2 photoreduction. Herein, adopting mixed halides strategy, the activity of all-inorganic perovskites toward CO2 reduction is enhanced sharply under simulated sunlight without photosensitizer, meanwhile maintaining high selectivity of CO and CH4 production. Via regulating ratio of Br and Cl, the yield of CO and CH4 changes obviously and the optimized catalyst is CsPb(Br0.5/Cl0.5)3 with a total yield of CO and CH4 up to 875 μmol/g (selectivity of 99%) which outperforms any other reported halide perovskites and is 4.5 and 9.1 folds higher than that of CsPbBr3 and CsPbCl3 under the same condition. The efficient charge separation and moderate stability in mixed-halide perovskites may account for the excellent performance in CO2 reduction. This study may provide a new strategy in design of high performance and low-cost halide perovskite materials for photocatalysis.
coredata.dc:title: Enhanced CO2 photoreduction via tuning halides in perovskites
